text: is an underwater volcano (seamount) of the Hawaiianâ€“Emperor seamount chain in the Pacific Ocean.Tarduno, John A. et al. "The Emperor Seamounts: southward motion of the Hawaiian hotspot plume in Earth's mantle," Science, 22 August 2003, pp. 1064-1069 DOI:10.1126/science.1086442; retrieved 2012-6-14. Meiji is an extinct volcano.Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute, "Life-cycle of Hawaiian hot spot volcanoes" ; retrieved 2012-6-14. The seamount is also known as "Meiji Guyot" because it has a flat top.Guyots are flat-topped because they were once above sea level, and were worn down by the sea. This undersea geologic feature is also called a "guyot" or "tablemount".Geographic.org, "Meiji Guyot"; retrieved 2012-6-9. This seabed mountain is named after Emperor Meiji of Japan. The last eruption from Meiji seamount was 62 million years ago.
